addressleaf.section:
M: to the L: Chancelor Lo: Thr
ei
r, Lo: Buckhurst.

page.lettertext:
fol.110r
May yt please yo
r
good LLp: By o
r
Last of the xxij
th
of this p
r
sent, we signifyd
how farre we had
ceeded w
th
States g
na
ll
, upppon the poyntes of o
r
instructions
pounded unto them, immediatly after the dispatch of w
ch
letters, we pressed
againe some better resolution to o
r
fyrst
positions, wherunto they answered
that unlesse we would declare in wryting the reasons of o
r
mislike, of
their answers, and o
r
objections to their Appostills, they might not well
ceede to anye further Consultation, havinge alreadye delivered as
muche, as might be yealded unto, consyderinge the p
r
sent state of
their Contrye and affayres. Hereuppon to avoyde losse of tyme we
p
r
sently framed some fewe objections in wryting to the most
materyall poyntes of their appostill
w
ch
we deli
v
ed in their assemblye,
enlarginge the same by speache as we thought Convenient for their
better inducem
t
to allowe of o
r
demand
, and w
th
all did exibite the
rest of the matters, we had to
pounde all at once, to the ende we
might receyve some spedye answer to the wholle.
The xxiij
th
we receyved from them an Acte sent unto us by
Aersens
their secretarye, signifying their intentions to send or report
to their Provinces, as well o
r
objections, as o
r
second
positions,
And therfore desyred of us, yf we had anye other thinge in chardge
that might requyre their Answer, we would vouchsaffe to deli
v
yt
altogether, to be imparted w
th
the rest to their Superiours, whose
myndes and resolutions they purposed to have uppon the whole matters
of o
r
negotiations. We marvayling greatlye at his determinac
o
n
of the States to send againe to their Provinces, and therby to detract
the tyme, havinge by their Act declared a sufficiencye of Authoritye
in themselffes to treate and conclude w
th
us uppon the matters of o
r
chardge, We resorted unto them, and delyvered o
r
opinions, howe
needelesse yt was for them to take that course in respect That by the
19
th
Article of the Treatye, ther was alreadye graunted unto her
Ma
tie
and to the
Counsell of State
full power, and Authoritye, for the esta-
blishinge of all thinges that did concerne the good of the Common
weale, or matters of their martiall disciplyne, And that o
r
second
positions in effect tended but to an explanation of that Article.
This Article we did purposely from the beginning forbeare
to urge, supposinge that they of themselffes, in their answers unto
us, would allwayse have had consyderation therof, But such was
eyther their o
v
sight, in not consyderinge the substance of the
Article, or their skill, and Conninge advisedly to o
m
itt the
same as when they
ceyved us resolutely to presse th'observance
of that
fol.110v
[.]
of that Article: They rose from the Table in a sorte amazed
and retyred themselffs into another roome, to advise uppon their answer
wher after they had conferred more then a quarter of an hower, they
retourned, and by their President
John Vander Wacke
, one of the deputed
for
Zeland
, They deli
v
ed that forasmuch that her Ma
tie
had refused the
Souverayngntye of their Provinces being offred unto her, they supposed
she would not seeke yt now by vertue of the Contract. That to have more
heades or Souveraignes in their State then one, was to make the same a
monster; That the Authoritye graunted to her Ma
tie
by this Article, was
but for one tyme only to be exercysed, w
ch
was alreadye executed by
the Comminge of the
Earle of Leceister
as her Ma
ties
generall into thes Contries
And that therfore th'effect of that Article was alreadye
fourmed, and the
Article vanished. we disprouved their conceipt of anye purpose of
demaund of Souveraigntye in her Ma
tie
, by requyringe the Authoritye
yealded by that Article, and declared that the same was not graunted
to her Ma
tie
alone, but to her and the Counsell of State joynctly,
who were all their Compatriot
and of their owne bodye selected
and chosen by the severall Provinces, as
sons to whom the exer-
cyse of their souveraigntye was Committed, and such as in all
former tymes, w
ch
the Gouverno
r
of their Provinces enjoyed the like
commoditye
Authoritie
under their Princes. We likewise disprouved
their construction made of the Article, by comparinge the sence
therof w
th
the whole bodye of the treatye, and made yt appeare unto
them that the same was no more extinct then the rest that con-
tynewed in being, and so
secuted the infyrmation therof by
as manye Argum
t
as we could; In the end after longe debating
and no alteration in their conceipt and opinion touchinge th'explicac
o
n
of the Article appearinge, we were forced to use (though in tem
at
manner) some rounde speaches unto them; signyfying how sorye
we were to discover their backward affections to her Ma
tie
so
clearely manyfested by this Conference. They
tested never-
thelesse their greate devotion toward
her Ma
tie
, And fynally
prayed, that what they sayd to the purpose of the Article, might
not be taken as an answer, but that they coould imparte o
r
Allegac
o
n
to their Provinces, and receyve their
sen
censure
and resolution to
the sayd Article; we suspectinge what the Princes might
resolve uppon their construction to be made of the sence of the
Article, answered that yf they mente to put the matter in
deliberation amonge their Provinces we would in like sorte
reco
m
ende the same to the interpretation of yo
r
LL. and the rest that
were in Co
m
ission from her Ma
tie
in concluding the treatye
wherof
fol.111r
wherof yt may please yo
r
LL: to have good consyderation, And (yf yt
may seeme so good unto yo
u
) that the opinions of some of the best
learned in the Civil Lawe may be taken uppon the substaunce of the
Article, and signyfyed hether w
th
yo
r
LL: construction of the same
that they may not evade from us in this poynt, The rather for
that we
ceyve we shall hardlye establish any sufficient au-
thoritye in the Gouverno
r
and Counsell of state here, yf we
yealde to the Annullinge of that Article, being certaynly enformed
that some of this Assemblye have alreadye before hand geven Caveat
to
their Provinces to beware how they accord to the Gouveno
rs
, and Coun-
sell of State the power geven by the Contract, bycause they shall
therin yeald them Regall Authoritye, w
ch
by the States g
na
ll
is chalenged by tradition from the people to remayne in them,
and can by no meanes endure that a Gouverno
r
From her Ma
tie
w
th
the Counsell should be invested w
th
that Authoritye.
By their resesse (as they tearme yt) to their
vinces ther
will much delay be used, and is in o
r
Conceipt done of
purpose to wynne tyme, That they may see what successe may
happen in
France
yf the
K
: become possessed of
Paris,
according
wherunto they will streighten, or enlarge themselffes, in allow-
inge the demaund
made by her Ma
tie
. Not that they will
hastelye become French, but that they shall therby discerne
how the enemy may be imployed, and hyndred from anye
notable attempt againste them and soe measure ther owne
nesse
necessitie to be releeved by her Ma
tie
.
The resoluc
o
ns that shall now be drawen from the
vinces
to the Matters we have
now
poded
p
ou
ded
will yeald the
matters
answers
of
the states therunto
soe
absolute, as ou
r
further replies or objections
will nothinge alter the same, or p
r
vaile to amend
or reforme
anie jott of
ther determinacons, havinge alredie
at
at great lenght in
manie metinges Delivered
as much and as manie Reasons on her Ma
ties
te in our poore oppini-
nions in the knowledge we have of the p
r
sent state of these Cuntries
and humours of the men maie besaide to advaunce the severall matters we
have p
r
pounded. and therfor nowe after we
shall
shall have conferred w
th
the councell of state to whome we mene to Repaire, to
arnehem.
I
Thomas wilkes shall have nothinge to doe heare but to attend
the
answer
vinces and States w
ch
I looke to Receive about the end of
septemb
r
nexte and not before in the mene time for seeinge the
events
as it
fol.111v
hereof I motioned unto the states (as of my selfe) that they would like of
my Repeire to
England
p
r
tendinge some
ticuler Cause of myne owne
and
to
returne heither at such time as I mighte understand from them
of ther Resolucons taken in the poyntes of my negotiac
o
n wherunto they
would in noe sorte Condissend but intracted me to staie for that they
desired to growe to sume conclution uppon the Condicons I had deli
v
ed
concerning ther trad to
Spaigne
./
Our purpose of conference w
th
the Councell, is to move them to Joyne
w
th
us in claiminge the authoritie graunted by the Contracte, and because
I Thomas Bodly by the knowledge I have of ther Dispositions, do thinke
they wilbe hardly induced to concure with us publiquely in that behalffe
by reason they are for the most part unwilling to offend the States, as
fearing to be removed from their places, or otherwise disgraced, we
intend to urge them uppon their oath taken for the observance of the contract
and herin never the lesse to be advised, and to use such Course and
discretion, as may best farther the cause, and Least offend the on
e
or th'other, untill yt may be seene, what may be resolved, and
answered to o
r
positions. Thus farr for the matter of o
r
Instructions
wherin we do
test unto yo
r
LL: uppon o
r
alleageance to the Q: Ma
tie
we have travayled, and endeavoured all that we may, not only in
o
r
publicke conference w
th
the States gen
r
all, but w
th
the cheifest
of them in
ticular, And cannot for o
r
lyves forejudge, what
successe will followe of o
r
Actions herein, suche and so strange hath
binne the manner of ther
cedinges w
th
us usinge both rough and mylde
Communicac
o
ns w
th
them though without offence.
We received from the Luiet
e
nte of the
brill
a l
er
date the xxv
th
of this p
rse
nt, adv
r
tising that the vic
t
aler havinge brought Corne
to the Towne, for the
vision of the Garrison wher the orders ar
now to be put in excecuc
o
n: The Burghm
rs
of the Towne have
inhibbited that neither the millers shall grinde the Corne, neither the
bakers bake the same, wher by the apearred a resoluc
o
n in the people
to appose them selves them selves against that
te of the orders for
the victalinge of the souldiers and because for sum reasons aleged
in our former l
res
, we thinke it is not fitt at this time to make
a garboyle betwene the towne and the garrison we have thoughte
good to adv
r
tise the Luietenante go
v
no
r
to forbear the execuc
o
n of the
orders in that poynt untill yo
r
LL. might be adv
r
tised of this apposic
o
n
(which we Conceive to grow under hande from the state) that we might
recive Your pleasure and direction therin and trewly my lorde we finde
both the States
fol.112r
And by the Townes who sithence we beganne to Treat here
have sent unto us ther Burghm
ars
and principall officers
to praie that the vicutallinge might be forborne that yt is
soe offencive to the
inhabitant
of the
Townes as it will bred agreat [alean
a
n]
to the towne
of the people from her Ma
tie
for the apparell
of the souldiers the States and townes do not much
mislike, and to the souldier him selfe ther is nothinge more
offencive thenn the vittuall which (as they complaine in all the
Garrisons) is not only very corrupte but sould unto them
at higher Rates then is aforded them by the townes and what
furder inc
o
veniences doe growe therof will beste appeare
unto your Lordship by the artikells latly sent unto you by
the governor and captaines of
the
Berghen
wher w
th
we
have bine mad acquented and find them all worthie of
Considerac
o
n w
ch
we must humblie refer to your good LL:
and so take our leave from the
Haghe
the xxix
th
of
July - 1590./
You
r
LLo: humbly to Co
m
aund
Tho: Wylkes
Tho Badley
